answers.author: Martha Perego
answers.text:
ICMA’s 2011 Compensation Survey was sent to over 7,000 cities, counties and towns that have a Chief Appointed Officer (CAO) position.  We heard back from 2556 local governments for a 36% response rate.  Here is the key data on severance: 
   Seventy-seven percent of respondents report that they are eligible for severance pay.  Most commonly, severance is paid when termination is triggered by the employer.  Interestingly, 20% of the managers responding who work in larger organizations (250,000-499,999) reported being able to collect severance if they left voluntarily.
   Eighty percent of managers have fixed not sliding scale severance pay.  The average is 28 weeks of severance pay.

author: Eric Norenberg
text: The severance compensation in our community is defined (salary and housing allowance) in the City Charter and the length (three months) is fixed in the Charter as well.  Within a few months, the City Council must appoint a Charter Review Committee, so I am gathering information for possible amendments.  The current text was approved by voters in 1994, so I would like know if there is any data showing the average length of severance compensation for City Managers in recent years?  Thanks!
title: Current Average Length of Severance Compensation
